messages.subject: Shin-Ko Meito Zufu.
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, Although the title is familiar, I can t seem to locate this book in my library so I cannot comment on the contents. Regards, Cary Condell Condell &
messages.messageBody:
Curran,
Although the title is familiar, I can't seem
to locate this book in my library so I cannot
comment on the contents.

Regards,
Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

Curran Campbell wrote:

> Cary, Jim, Afu, Jinsoo and others;
>
> To expand and clarify my last question-
> Is this book useful/reliable? I have seen a few
> pages and got the impression that it was more of a
> publication of various excellent swords. I did not
> pick up on that they were all -famous-.
> As is sometimes the case with various Japanese
> books, my impression was that some of the swords
> were
> ones the owners wanted to get more face time and in
> print. Sort of a Public Relations photo opp. for a
> sword.
>
> If it is not an insightful or reliable reference,
> I'd be more inclined to just stick with the Tokubetsu
> Juyo Token Zufu(s).
>
> Thank you for any advice on this work,
>
> Curran

messages.subject: Fwd: Re: [nihonto] ID this book:
messages.msgSnippet: Cary, Jim, Afu, Jinsoo and others; To expand and clarify my last question- Is this book useful/reliable? I have seen a few pages and got the impression that it
messages.messageBody:
Cary, Jim, Afu, Jinsoo and others;

To expand and clarify my last question-
Is this book useful/reliable? I have seen a few
pages and got the impression that it was more of a
publication of various excellent swords. I did not
pick up on that they were all -famous-.
As is sometimes the case with various Japanese
books, my impression was that some of the swords
were
ones the owners wanted to get more face time and in
print. Sort of a Public Relations photo opp. for a
sword.

If it is not an insightful or reliable reference,
I'd be more inclined to just stick with the Tokubetsu
Juyo Token Zufu(s).

Thank you for any advice on this work,

Curran
>
>
>
